Dear Ms. Edmon:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
06/24/22 and 06/28/2022. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is
required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also
violations of the MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from
the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 For repeat violations, identify why the previous CAP was unsuccessful.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (734) 395-0920.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the
following information prior to employment or at the time
specified in this rule:
(j) A written evaluation of the employee's performance
within 30 days of the completion of the probationary period
or within 180 days, whichever is less, and a written
evaluation of the employee’s performance annually
thereafter.
One of the existing employee files did not show documentation
of the employee’s annual performance evaluation.
R 400.4127 Staff to resident ratio.
(1) The licensee shall develop and adhere to a written staff-
to-resident ratio formula for direct care workers.
(4) When residents are asleep or otherwise outside of the
direct supervision of staff, staff shall perform variable
interval, eye-on checks of residents. The time between the
variable interval checks shall not exceed fifteen minutes.
One of the staff interviewed reported they complete 15 minute
checks but not in variable intervals, when the youth go to their
bedrooms for the evening.
Repeat violation: SI 2022C0446002, corresponding CAP
11/23/2021, the facility must identify why the previous CAP
was not successful.
R 400.4128 Initial staff orientation and ongoing staff training.
(3) The licensee shall document that each direct care
worker participated in a minimum of 50 clock hours of
planned training within the first year of employment and a
minimum of 25 clock hours of training annually thereafter.
4

One of the six existing employee files reviewed did not
document the required 25 hours of training required annually.
2.) The facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) The facility is in compliance will all additional MDDHS Contract/Policy
requirements.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was not provided technical assistance.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was not provided consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
licensing period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
The facility has not had to submit any corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
During this period, the facility changed their Chief Administrator and closed the short
term program, which resulted in significant improvement and oversight. There was
only one complaint received that is currently being investigated. Although not
completed, it does not appear that there will be any licensing violations in that open
investigation. During this period there was only one restraint performed. In fact, there
has only been this one restraint in over seven months. The incident report was
reviewed, and the facility documentation of the incident was appropriate. The facility
is in the process of reviewing their restraint policy and will be providing updated policy
if required before the due date. The facility hired a nurse in January 2022 and a
second Nurse in March 2022 to ensure compliance with medication refills, dispensing,
and training of staff. The nurse was interviewed and provided a detailed report of the
medication refill and dispensing process. There have been no concerns reported by
staff or youths regarding medication refills or dispensing during the reporting period.
This notes a marked improvement in this area.
During this period monthly unannounced on-site inspections were completed, and
youths and staff were interviewed. The facility was well maintained and clean. The
youth bedrooms were clean and furnished, bathrooms were clean, medications refills
and dispensing were reviewed, and meal menus were posted. Ample food was
observed in the cottages. I completed interviews with staff, who reported feeling
5

supported by management and believe the agency is meeting the youth’s needs. I
interviewed three youths. The youth interviewed reported feeling safe, receiving
weekly individual and group therapy, participating in activities, receiving prescribed
medication, and all their needs are being met. There were no concerns noted by the
youth or staff.
The facility is currently fully staffed and are in ratio. They are also working with the
Residential Collaboration and Technical Assistance Unit (RCTAU) and have been
meeting weekly with the Specialist.
The facility has improved in their implementation of CAPs. They completed all their
CAPs from the prior period successfully, which is evident by the reduced number of
complaints. Area of focus were staff sufficiency, supervision, maintaining ratio,
following facility policies/procedures, staff training, and medication refills and
dispensing. The facility addressed these issues by hiring staff including two nurses,
updating medication policy, retraining of supervisors and staff, and weekly meetings
are held by the clinical team and managers to discuss and address any concerns
regarding each resident. CAP compliance has been verified through review of training
logs, meeting notes, interviews with supervisors, direct care staff, nurse, and youths.
The management team is very involved in the day-to-day operation which has had a
positive impact on the facility performance, services, and improved their compliance.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility be issued a
renewal of their Regular license.
